speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Tut, I have the best armor of the world.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Would it were day!

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: You have an excellent armor, but let my

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: horse have his due.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: It is the best horse of Europe.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: Will it never be morning?

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: My Lord of Orléans and my Lord High Constable,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: you talk of horse and armor?

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: You are as well provided of both as any

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: prince in the world.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: What a long night is this! I will not change

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: my horse with any that treads but on four pasterns.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: Çà, ha! He bounds from the earth, as if his

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: entrails were hairs, le cheval volant, the Pegasus, qui

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: a les narines de feu. When I bestride him, I soar; I

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: am a hawk; he trots the air. The earth sings when he

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: touches it. The basest horn of his hoof is more

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: musical than the pipe of Hermes.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: He’s of the color of the nutmeg.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: And of the heat of the ginger. It is a beast for

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: Perseus. He is pure air and fire, and the dull

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: elements of earth and water never appear in him,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: but only in patient stillness while his rider mounts

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: him. He is indeed a horse, and all other jades you

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: may call beasts.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Indeed, my lord, it is a most absolute and

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: excellent horse.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: It is the prince of palfreys; his neigh is like

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: the bidding of a monarch, and his countenance

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: enforces homage.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: No more, cousin.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: Nay, the man hath no wit that cannot, from

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: the rising of the lark to the lodging of the lamb,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: vary deserved praise on my palfrey. It is a theme as

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: fluent as the sea. Turn the sands into eloquent

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: tongues, and my horse is argument for them all. ’Tis

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: a subject for a sovereign to reason on, and for a

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: sovereign’s sovereign to ride on, and for the world,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: familiar to us and unknown, to lay apart their

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: particular functions and wonder at him. I once writ

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: a sonnet in his praise and began thus: “Wonder of

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: nature—”

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: I have heard a sonnet begin so to one’s

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: mistress.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: Then did they imitate that which I composed

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: to my courser, for my horse is my mistress.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: Your mistress bears well.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: Me well—which is the prescript praise and

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: perfection of a good and particular mistress.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Nay, for methought yesterday your mistress

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: shrewdly shook your back.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: So perhaps did yours.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Mine was not bridled.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: O, then belike she was old and gentle, and

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: you rode like a kern of Ireland, your French hose

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: off, and in your strait strossers.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: You have good judgment in horsemanship.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: Be warned by me, then: they that ride so, and

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: ride not warily, fall into foul bogs. I had rather have

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: my horse to my mistress.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: I had as lief have my mistress a jade.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: I tell thee, constable, my mistress wears his

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: own hair.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: I could make as true a boast as that if I had

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: a sow to my mistress.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: “Le chien est retourné à son propre vomissement,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: et la truie lavée au bourbier.” Thou mak’st use

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: of anything.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Yet do I not use my horse for my mistress,

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: or any such proverb so little kin to the purpose.

speaker: RAMBURES
text: My Lord Constable, the armor that I saw in

speaker: RAMBURES
text: your tent tonight, are those stars or suns upon it?

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Stars, my lord.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: Some of them will fall tomorrow, I hope.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: And yet my sky shall not want.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: That may be, for you bear a many superfluously,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: and ’twere more honor some were away.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Ev’n as your horse bears your praises—

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: who would trot as well were some of your brags

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: dismounted.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: Would I were able to load him with his

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: desert! Will it never be day? I will trot tomorrow a

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: mile, and my way shall be paved with English faces.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: I will not say so for fear I should be faced

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: out of my way. But I would it were morning, for I

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: would fain be about the ears of the English.

speaker: RAMBURES
text: Who will go to hazard with me for twenty

speaker: RAMBURES
text: prisoners?

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: You must first go yourself to hazard ere you

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: have them.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text: ’Tis midnight. I’ll go arm myself.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: The Dauphin longs for morning.

speaker: RAMBURES
text: He longs to eat the English.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: I think he will eat all he kills.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: By the white hand of my lady, he’s a gallant

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: prince.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Swear by her foot, that she may tread out

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: the oath.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: He is simply the most active gentleman of

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: France.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Doing is activity, and he will still be doing.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: He never did harm, that I heard of.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Nor will do none tomorrow. He will keep

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: that good name still.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: I know him to be valiant.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: I was told that by one that knows him

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: better than you.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: What’s he?

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Marry, he told me so himself, and he said

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: he cared not who knew it.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: He needs not. It is no hidden virtue in him.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: By my faith, sir, but it is; never anybody

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: saw it but his lackey. ’Tis a hooded valor, and when

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: it appears, it will bate.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: Ill will never said well.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: I will cap that proverb with “There is

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: flattery in friendship.”

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: And I will take up that with “Give the devil

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: his due.”

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Well placed; there stands your friend for

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: the devil. Have at the very eye of that proverb with

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: “A pox of the devil.”

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: You are the better at proverbs, by how much

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: “A fool’s bolt is soon shot.”

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: You have shot over.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: ’Tis not the first time you were overshot.

speaker: MESSENGER
text: My Lord High Constable, the English lie

speaker: MESSENGER
text: within fifteen hundred paces of your tents.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Who hath measured the ground?

speaker: MESSENGER
text: The Lord Grandpré.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: A valiant and most expert gentleman.—

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Would it were day! Alas, poor Harry of England! He

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: longs not for the dawning as we do.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: What a wretched and peevish fellow is this

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: King of England to mope with his fat-brained

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: followers so far out of his knowledge.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: If the English had any apprehension, they

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: would run away.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: That they lack; for if their heads had any

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: intellectual armor, they could never wear such

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: heavy headpieces.

speaker: RAMBURES
text: That island of England breeds very valiant

speaker: RAMBURES
text: creatures. Their mastiffs are of unmatchable

speaker: RAMBURES
text: courage.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: Foolish curs, that run winking into the

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: mouth of a Russian bear and have their heads

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: crushed like rotten apples. You may as well say

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: that’s a valiant flea that dare eat his breakfast on the

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: lip of a lion.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Just, just; and the men do sympathize with

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: the mastiffs in robustious and rough coming on,

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: leaving their wits with their wives. And then give

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: them great meals of beef and iron and steel, they

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: will eat like wolves and fight like devils.

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: Ay, but these English are shrewdly out of

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: beef.

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: Then shall we find tomorrow they have

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: only stomachs to eat and none to fight. Now is it

speaker: CONSTABLE
text: time to arm. Come, shall we about it?

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: It is now two o’clock. But, let me see, by ten

speaker: ORLÉANS
text: We shall have each a hundred Englishmen.
